div1.head: "Report of the Yellow Fever Epidemic in the Department of Lambayeque," by Henry Rose Carter, February 25, 1921
div1.p:
REPORT OF THE YELLOW FEVER EPIDEMIC IN THE
DEPARTMENT OF LAMBAYEQUE
By
Henry R. Carter, M.D.

At the instance of the Salubridad I went to Ferrenafe on
January 20, 1921 to assist in determining the nature of the epidemic
there existing and to aid in planning the campaign against it in case
it proved to be yellow fever.

It is yellow fever. It is of about the same severity as
that I saw in Paita and elsewhere in the Department of Piura last
year. There is probably a somewhat larger proportion of deaths in
the same class of patients on account of less care being taken with
the sick. I saw no case in a native-born adult and I was in the
district eleven days. I saw seven dead children in two days. This
points to a general epidemic about twenty years ago.

Duration -- There is a history (Mr. Bonzi, Chiclayo) of an epi-
demic with some deaths and of unknown nature at Jayanca a month or
two before such reports from Ferrenafe; also of the death of a man
(Father Pita, Pacasmayo) from Catacaos, at a haciendo near Ferranafe
in June or July believed to be from yellow fever, and several cases
about a month later at the hacienda to which he first came.

From the stage of the epidemic the infection must have been
introduced into Ferrenafe not later than early October.

Extent -- Ferrenafe is thoroughly infected, probably past the acme
of the epidemic. From the duration of the epidemic and the prevalence of
the disease in Ferrenafe it is well nigh certain that it exists in a
-2-
number of places outside of this town. I saw a case in Chiclayo
and two cases, one dead, in Lambayeque. There is some reason to be-
lieve that some of the smaller places to the north and east have
passed through the epidemic and are now in a measure immunized. Ste-
gomyia were found everywhere we looked for them.
B. Campaign.

This is two fold: (1) To limit the epidemic, i.e. to
prevent its extension to parts not
yet infected.

(2) To eliminate it from the infected
district

Of the two the first is by far the most important. The fever
is quite certainly in many of the towns and villages of the Chiclayo
district, but if it can be confined to it its elimination should not
be difficult and it would be certain, as the district, while thickly
settled, is not a large one. Should its extension not be opposed it
will go into the populous regions of the Department of Libertad and
continue south as far as climatic conditions allow. To the south we
found stegomyia abundant in all towns, and all haciendas save one ex-
amined.

There is of course danger of the reinfection of the Depart-
ment of Piura to the north if the stegomyia index therein is allowed
to rise sufficiently. There is, however, a certain amount - in some
places a high degree - of immunization in this Department and at pre-
sent the stegomyia index is - or rather on January 1 the stegomyia in-
dex was - very low: too low for the propagation of yellow fever.

The Method of Limiting the Epidemic relied on is to so control the
production of stegomyia that their number is reduced below that neces-
sary for the propogation of yellow fever even if it be introduced, i e
to render the place “non-infectable” by yellow fever. Naturally the
same method would eliminate yellow fever were it, unknown to us, already
existant.

This was urgently advised and to an extent attempted for the
Chiclayo and Ferranafe district last year to protect it against the
Piura epidemic. Had this been done there would have been no yellow fever
in Peru this year and unless it be done, and done effectively, the ex-
perience of Lambayeque will be repeated in Libertad and further south.

There is no question as to the danger and no question as to
the method of avoiding it. It is much cheaper both in money and lives
to prevent the spread of fever to new places than to eliminate it when
established. Many lives and some thousands of pounds had been saved had
the anti-stegomyia campaign advised for the Chiclayo district last year
been carried out. The whole department of Libertad should be thus
treated - the province of Pacasmayo especially.

Method of Controlling the Production of Stegomyia. Doctor Hanson
and myself have agreed on a method of controlling stegomyia breeding in
depositos of water which was think is generally - not universally - appli-
cable in these districts. If so it will be a marked improvement on
those used last year: as efficient and cheaper (requiring less personnel)
and simpler (requiring less skill and experience). It would take sometime
to describe it and as Doctor Hanson will do so by circular and otherwise
it seems unnecessary. It involves no new principle, simply emptying com-
-4-
pletely and drying every container once in seven days instead of ex-
amining them for larvae, which we found in 90% of the depositos.

Administration. It goes without saying that the officer directly
in charge of this work should make his headquarters in the infected
district, probably at Chiclayo and should have full control of it.
He should have sufficient funds ready at all times and with a suf-
ficient personnel absolutely at his order; the central office giving
him all the support possible. It is desirable that he be immune to
yellow fever so that he can move freely from infected to non-infected
places - if not so by previous attack he should be vaccinated. There
is good reason to believe that this confers a temporary immunity.

The Sanitary Outlook. This is to be considered both in regard
to the elimination of the present epidemic in Lambayeque and its
limitation to that area.

For the first and compared with the condition last year in
Piura the area involved is much more densely populated than that in
Piura and the breeding conditions of stegomyia could scarcely be
worse. The large botijas are in well-nigh universal use and these
are the worst of all possible depositos for stegomyia -- meaning the
most difficult to control. On the other hand nowhere is there the
scarcity of water which was such a handicap in Paita and much of
the laundry is done in the streams, lessening the amount of water needed
in the houses. Also we have a certain number of trained men for in-
spectors and we begin in the majority of the towns coincident with or
before the epidemic, thus preventing as well as controlling it. The sanitation of practically the whole district is to be undertaken at
-5-
once from the beginning of the work.

For the second preventing the spread of fever to new territory
the outlook is unquestionably better than last year. Then, owing I am
told to the opposition of the authorities in the district to be pro-
tected (that of Chiclayo and Ferranfe) practically nothing was accom-
plished.

The feeling of both authorities and people in the zone south
of Lambayeque is very different. Doctor Hanson, I accompanying him,
made a hurried trip from Chiclayo to Salaverry by land visiting a number
of towns and haciendas. The disposition of the people in this section
left nothing to be desired. They will cooperate fully in carrying out
the protective measures outlined to them. The haciendados generally
promise to themselves undertake the sanitation of their establishments,
some of which are towns.

Pressed and handled wisely this campaign to limit the epidemic
will succeed.

Vaccine. I have not time to discuss the use of Noguch's vaccine.
Admitting that its use for men is in the experimental stage yet the
animal experiments are such that I would recommend its use freely; as
freely as it can be pressed in infected places to immunize the population
and thus raise the allowable critical number of stegomyia for the place.
Could it be used universally as vaccine for smallpox is and give the same
immunity, we could render towns immune to yellow fever from absence of the
human host temporarily at any rate. It cannot, I think, at present take
the place of control of stegomyia production.
